results.title: For you madam. [67/10] = Pour vous madame
results.brief_description: Cinemagazine items: Caussade, the French hat making capital; Shoes and gloves for Winter ‘67 at the 25th International Leather Show; Winter sports clothing; Artist Francoise Adnet shows her paintings. Full transcription inside film can.

results.title: For you madam = Pour vous madame
results.brief_description: French cinemagazine items: 1. Connaissance de la France - celebrates France’s 8th century first gothic building, Sants Cathedral, consecrated by Pope Alexander III in 1164. 2. In 1940, France’s National Geographical Institute set out to make a new map of the country, scheduled for completion in 1980. This segment focuses on the project’s progress. 3. Looks at an exhibition of masterpieces hosted by a French regional gallery which will eventually reach the Louvre. 4. ‘Foire de Paris = Paris Fair’ - presents some of the highlights. 5. Visits a bull-ring in Southern France which although controversial, attracts thousands of spectators. Shows the different stages of a bull-fight.

results.title: For whom the bell tolls
results.brief_description: A romantic drama set in 1937, during the Spanish Civil War. Gary Cooper plays Robert Jordan, an American who has joined a guerilla group and has been assigned to blow-up a Falangist controlled Bridge. He meets and falls in love with a young woman, played by Ingrid Bergman, who joined the group after her brutal treatment at the hands of the enemy. Written by Dudley Nichols, based on the novel by Ernest Hemingway, which was unanimously voted the best novel of the year in 1941 by the Pulitzer Prize committee, but was vetoed for political reasons. Cast also includes Akim Tamiroff, Arturo de Cordova and Katina Paxinou. Music by Victor Young. Photography by Ray Rennahan. Edited by Sherman Todd and John F. Link. (Awards: Katina Paxinou, Oscar 1943, Best Supporting Actress)

results.title: For the term of his natural life
results.creator_credit: Rob Stewart, Patricia Payne, Paynes Schiller Productions and Filmco
results.brief_description: Colin Friels plays Rufus Dawes in Marcus Clarke’s epic novel. Forced to leave his England home after being disinherited by the man he believed to be his natural father, Rufus is dealt another cruel blow when, on learning his father’s real identity, is falsely arrested for his murder and sentenced to transportation to Van Dieman’s Land for the term of his natural life. Once there, Rufus experiences many hardships and cruel acts, mainly at the hands of other hardened convicts but also from Lieutenant Frere, the feared and brutal ruler of the prison colonies. One thing that helps Rufus through this time is Sylvia, the daughter of Major Vickers with whom he holds a special but long forgotten bond. It is Rufus’ courage and will to survive that maintains him through many escape attempts and the desire for freedom that make him an extrodinary person - barely living on the land that is pure hell.

results.title: For the record - George Best: a profile
results.brief_description: A profile of George Best (interviewed by Michael Parkinson), his origins in Belfast, family background, and his “pop-star” status as a gifted footballer. Includes football footage and interviews with family friends and club representatives. Emphasises the competing elements in his life, his status as a footballer versus his celebrity status.

results.title: For the love of...Lolo
results.creator_credit: Ayen Guinto, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: When Ayen Guinto lost her beloved ‘Lolo’, her family lost the glue holding them together. She remembers him and wonders if the family should use his life as inspiration to move forward.

results.title: For the love of the game
results.creator_credit: Sam Raimi, Amy Robinson, Armyan Bernstein, Universal Pictures, TIG Productions, Mirage Enterprises and Beacon Communication
results.brief_description: Marking a shift for sometime action/horror director Raimi, “For the Love of the Game” explores the tensions and romance of adult relationships. Billy Chapel (Kevin Costner) is an ageing baseball sports star who is coming to the end of his career. His commitment to the game has meant that his relationship with Jane (Kelly Preston) is suffering and she announces that she is leaving him. With both his love life and his sports career in tatters, Billy has to make crucial decisions about what kind of future he wants for himself. Based on the novel by Michael Shaara, “For the Love of the Game” is best when it is detailing the training, performance and expertise of the sportsmen. Preston and Costner make an attractive couple and Raimi’s assured, crisp direction makes for an unusually fast-paced romance.

results.title: For the love of dance
results.creator_credit: Cynthia Scott, David Wilson, John Smith, Michael McKennirey, Cynthia Scott/Canada Council, Adam Symansky and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A backstage look at Canada’s burgeoning dance industry, with seven of the country’s top professional dance companies. Filmed on location across North America, this documentary records the exacting daily grind of whistle-stop tours, exhausting repetitive practice, and little rest. Colourful excerpts highlight each troupe’s unique repertoire, as dancers give dazzling displays of physical control and grace. It is a moving tribute to the thousands of dancers who strive for perfection every day. Narrated by Adrienne Clarkson. (Awards: New York; Ronda-Malaga) N.B. Two minutes of footage is missing from the beginning of this film.

results.title: For the love of Benji
results.creator_credit: Joe Camp, Ben Vaughn and Mulberry Square
results.brief_description: In this sequel to the popular family movie “Benji”, our furry friend is in store for more heart stopping adventures. When holidaying in Greece with ladyfriend Tiffany and his newly adopted family, Benji and his friend are off to a bad start when they become embroiled in an international spy ring. Starring Cynthia Smith, Allen Fiuzat, Patsy Garrett and Ed Nelson.
